turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I don't want to challenge your answer to the question.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But, can you tell me what relevance did that have?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The issue that we have before us.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: It has this issue --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- on how much fee will be under the statute.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Yes, sir.
And I'll get to that point immediately, now that I have attempted to outline this administrative procedure which prompted some questions from the bench.
The question here is only one of after Mr. Hopkins was represented by Mr. Sharp in the judicial proceedings and was successful in his representation of that family.

The position of the respondent here is, very simply stated, 25% which is the maximum not to exceed that and not necessarily that, but not to exceed 25% applied to the base of only that which was paid directly to and for Mr. Hopkins, not including the benefits derivatively arrived in these proceedings to Mrs. Hopkins and the dependant children.

It is the position of the petitioner here and in the Sims case, which is pending before this Honorable Court on a petition for writ of certiorari to the Sixth Circuit which is my case, the position of the petitioner in both instances is that the clear intent of the Congress in this particular statutory provision was to limit a district judge exercising the discretion which is his, having seen the people, heard the case, and in a better position to evaluate the services rendered, to set a fee not to exceed 25% of the benefits resulting from the judgment.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Of all the claimants?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Of it -- yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, now, did your lawyer have an agreement with these other beneficiaries who Congress has tried to take care of --

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That they would be held responsible so their claim would be subject to this?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
In this Hopkins case, and of course I'm here as of counsel in this case, never having seen Mr. Hopkins and not knowing too much of the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, what I'm interested in is what authority did he have to sign away the rights of these other claimants --

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: He being --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If -- if they didn't sign?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: In the Hopkins case, Your Honor, Mr. Hopkins was the head of the family who signed the contingency agreement with Mr. Sharp, along with Mrs. Hopkins, and presumably for his minor children.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But “presumably,” but what authority did he have to sign it for his minor children and his wife?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: His wife signed it, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: She did?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Oh, yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, then, she's alright.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: As the signatory but, as I understand from the government, it has provided separate sums of benefits for the children.
And, you're asking that, without any agreement on their part or anyone acting for them, they be subjected to a lawyer's fee.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: That is not precisely, Mr. Justice Black.
May I say this, the children in the case are, of course, minors and they proceed through the office of their father, the head of the family.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Under the law?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: In normal circumstances, under the law.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Signing their contracts?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: For their benefit.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And their property?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Payable to the head of the family, Mr. Justice Black, for their benefit of course, there being no funds here to get any guardian appointed or being no necessity, their father being alive.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: There's no reliance here whatever on that contingent fee agreement, is there?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: So we're not talking about --

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: No, we're not.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Who signed it or who didn't sign it or anything else.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: No, it matters not whether there was a contingent fee agreement or not.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I know, we're talking about is the construction of the statute.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: That's right.
That was overcome by this statute.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And, that involved whether these children's properties that the Government has provided for them shall be subjected to attorney's fees by reason of a contract made by their father who is not their guardian.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Who was their natural guardian, Mr. Justice Black.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, that's alright.
He was not their legal guardian, was he?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: No, sir.
Not in the strict legal sense.
No, Mr. Justice Black.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Gearinger, now that you've answered that, I'd like to get back to your procedure again.
Now, let's suppose this, that you have two men, X and Y, who have the identical disability.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They proceed in exactly the same manner before this tribunal.
One of them is married and has three little infant children, like Mr. Hopkins.
The other one is a bachelor.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The Court hears -- they hear both cases and they both get an identical award.
For some reason rather, they go to the Courts with a lawyer, both are sustained.
Are you clear on what I've said?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, tell me.

What additional work would a lawyer have to do in the case of the man who had a wife and three children to do in order to get that decree over what the man with -- in the case of the man who was a bachelor?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Chief Justice.
The amount of legal professional work, undoubtedly, would not be too dissimilar.

They would be almost alike, except if at the hearing examiner's level if he were in -- if he were representing them there, he would of course call upon the wife, the children, the neighbors, or anyone else to appear in that hearing and, herein, testify.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And, testify to what?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: They testify as --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They would have to have that for the other man.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: -- and testify as to the state of disability of the head of the family.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, you'd have to have other witnesses for the bachelor just the same whether they were wife and children or not, or it might be a mother and a father, brothers and sisters.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: In most cases, Mr. Chief Justice, the hearing is conducted on exhibits of medical reports --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I know.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: -- and the hearing and the claimant, so --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I know but the evidentiary, whatever --

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Whatever it is, would the evidentiary requirements be any different in the case of the bachelor or the man with three children?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Not on the substantive question of the disability of the head of family.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Alright.
Now, what in addition to that would they have to prove for the man who had a wife and three children?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: The relationship of those dependants to that claimant and their entitlement as his dependants.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Then they would have to ask two questions, one for the wife, “are you the wife?”
And she would say, yes, and you'd have to ask somebody if the children --

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Children --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- were his children.
And, that's the only difference?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: At the hearing examiner's level, that is the only difference.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Alright.

Now -- but still you are of the opinion that Congress couldn't limit or shouldn't limit the attorney's fees to a percentage of the original claimant himself but, on the other hand, you claim that Congress intended that a lawyer should take up to 25% of everything that comes in to the wife and to these children from the time their legs and arms were happed up until they're 21 years of age.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What do you ask them?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: We say this, Your Honor, that because the substantive question of disability is only the head of family claimant and that the benefits flowing to the wife and any dependants he may have, of course, is insulary to a determination of that first substantive question.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: So that, they would have no benefits had he not been found disabled.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Please start off here, don't you, at the statutory provision that limits the base to the amount of past benefits?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: That's right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Actually, what happens here if a lawyer is successful is that Mr. Hopkins is enti-- and his wife and children are entitled not only to pass the sums but to payments in the future.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: That is entirely correct, Mr. Justice Fortas.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: But the statute provides that the lawyer is confined to the amount that is received before Mr. Hopkins or Mr. Hopkins et al. has by reason of past accruals.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: That's entirely correct, Mr. Justice Fortas.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Not only that, then you have a 25% ceiling on that base and then you have the discretion of the Court to cut below that 25%.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Is that the way it works?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
And, in a practical sense, the Court does not in any case or in all cases automatically grant 25%, and he should not.
He should not --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Whether this 25% or not, and whether it is prospective or whether it is retrospective in the percentages that he's entitled to get, why should a man in the case with the wife and three children have to be entitled to get 25% of all of the payments that had been made to the wife and children if all he has to do is ask him if they are the wife or are the children?

Now, don't you think that Congress has a right to say that it shall be limited to that -- to just the claimant himself rather than the other, and don't you think in a case of this kind Congress intended to have a strict application so that these people would not be -- this kind of claimant should not be overborne by lawyer's contracts?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Your Honor, I'm trespassing upon my time, if the Court will allow any longer?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You can answer the question.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: I think that we have concerned ourselves and I apologize for concerning myself so much with the function of this organization and not to the interpretation of the statute.
We submitted to the Court yesterday and, if the Court please, I could now lodge with the Court we reproduced numerous copies of Judge Coleman's opinion that was coming at point from this.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: We've heard that draft yesterday.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: The --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: That --

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: -- position of -- yes, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: That was the unreported opinion --

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: That I asked.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: On my happy conscience, Your Honor, if the Court would like to have them lodged with the clerk.

The -- the simple and final position in this case of the Government on one hand, and the petitioner's on the other is that we say that it was the intention of the Congress not to divide and separate bachelors and fathers and mothers since the benefit went to the family unit, and there is no provision in the statute under consideration making such separation.

And, in that connection, the petitioner here in this case relies and urges very respectfully of this Court the position and interpretation taken by Chief Judge Hainsworth in the Fourth Circuit as being the proper interpretation of the statute.
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you just one more question.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Black.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I haven't yet heard, maybe it's not in the record, it's not yet mentioned, has this man been given payment on the basis of the total permanent incapacity?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Mr. Justice Black, unlike workman's compensation by percentages of permanent disability or non-permanent disability, these -- the benefits provided by the Social Security Act are measured on a formula concerning the payments he has made toward the trust fund and his eligibility by age and earning capacity in the past.
It's automatically computed.
It depends not upon a --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It depends on whether he's injured, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: It depends on whether he is disabled.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, what disability was found in this case?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: In this case, there is -- the Secretary found that he was totally disabled, and payment --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Totally disabled?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: With hernia?

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Under -- and a number of other things, combined together.
In the Secretary's determination, the administrative --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I haven't heard about the other things yet.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Well, we haven't touched upon those, Mr. Justice Black, because the Secretary has decided he was disabled and we have no dispute with that decision.
The Court found he was disabled and we have no dispute with that, so that the solitary question here is upon what base does the district judge fix a percentage fee.
That is the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I agree with you.
That's the only issue here.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: That's the only issue, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It would -- we've been going around pretty much.

turn.speaker: harold_h_gearinger
turn.label: Mr. Harold H. Gearinger
turn.text: Yes.
Thank you, Your Honor.
